discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
(A) Undertow for Spring Reactive https://undertow.io/ See https://springhow.com/spring-boot-undertow/

<dependency>
 <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
 <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-web</artifactId>
 <exclusions>
 <exclusion>
 <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
 <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-tomcat</artifactId>
 </exclusion>
 </exclusions>
</dependency>
<dependency>
 <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
 <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-undertow</artifactId>
</dependency>

(B) Jetty for Spring Reactive. 

(C) wrong, it is 8080, not 8088

(D) true

(E) wrong, use in-memory with Spring Data JPA or Spring Security or declaring H2 database in pom.xml or build.gradle .

Selected Answer: CD
(A) Undertow for Spring Reactive https://undertow.io/ 

(B) Jetty for Spring Reactive. 

(C) true, 

(D) true, 

(E) wrong, use in-memory with Spring Data JPA or Spring Security or declaring H2 database in pom.xml or build.gradle .

comments.content: I have mistake, default port is 8080, not 8088, make D is wrong.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Went though the VMWare Spring Boot course again for Configuration of WAR and JAR deployments and it confirms what the commenters below said.

Selected Answer: AC
Default embedded servlet container is Tomcat. Jetty and Undertow can be used instead of it.

choices.B: Jetty is the default servlet container.
choices.E: Spring MVC starts up an in-memory database by default.
choices.A: The default embedded servlet container can be replaced with Undertow.
choices.D: The default port of the embedded servlet container is 8088.
choices.C: Spring Boot starts up an embedded servlet container by default.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true regarding a Spring Boot-based Spring MVC application? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: This question was in my exam.

Selected Answer: AC
A: true. 
Spring Data MongoDB https://spring.io/projects/spring-data-mongodb .
Spring Data Neo4j https://spring.io/projects/spring-data-neo4j
Spring Data Redis https://spring.io/projects/spring-data-redis

B: False

C: true. For example: Spring Data Envers 
Optional<T> findById(ID primaryKey);

D: wrong. For also NoSQL, not “relational database access only”

E: wrong. Spring Data and Spring MVC are friends.

comments.content: B is wrong, Spring Data not always use JPA annotation, for example case NoSQL.

discussion.content: why not A and C , because Spring Data can implement NoSQL DB too, like MongoDB, Neo4j and Redis... maybe mainly relationa data bases but NoSQL too. For this reason I believe D is wrong

questions.question_text: Which following statements are true about Spring Data? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Spring Data works by applying the JPA annotations to data stores such as MongoDB, Neo4j, and Redis.
choices.C: Spring Data can greatly reduce the amount of “boilerplate” code typically needed for data access.
choices.E: Spring Data cannot be used together with Spring MVC.
choices.A: Spring Data implementations exist for many data storage types, such as MongoDB, Neo4j, and Redis.
choices.D: Spring Data is specifically designed for JPA, JDBC, and relational database access only.
Modify the LegacySingleton class by adding the @Autowired annotation to the instance variable.
choices.C: It is not possible without modifying the LegacySingleton class, the constructor must be public.
choices.B: Return an instance of LegacySingleton using the new keyword from a @Bean method.
choices.A: Call LegacySingleton.getInstance() from within a @Bean method and return the instance.

questions.question_text: Which two options are application slices that can be tested with Spring Boot Testing? (Choose two.)
Using declarative transaction management, which situation will cause a transaction to roll back by default?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
See https://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/transaction/annotation/Transactional.html#rollbackFor()
"By default, a transaction will be rolled back on RuntimeException and Error but not on checked exceptions (business exceptions)."

choices.C: When any uncaught checked exception is thrown
choices.B: When any type of exception is thrown, checked or unchecked
choices.D: Only when a Spring-specific exception is thrown
choices.A: When any uncaught unchecked exception is thrown
